headline: Birth Control Pills, 1957
snippet: Enovid had been used against menstrual disorders since 1957, but May 10, 1960, was when The Times reported its approval as the birth control pill.

headline: The Right to Birth Control
snippet: A reader responds to a Nicholas D. Kristof column about the need for access to birth control.

headline: Birth Control Over Baldness
snippet: New contraceptives, still in trials, could be a powerful tool in fighting global poverty.

headline: Birth Control Doesn’t Have to Mean the Pill
snippet: Alternatives to the popular pill, like intrauterine devices, hormonal implants or injections, may be more convenient, more effective and cheaper in the long run.

headline: Choosing a Birth Control Method
snippet: Today's Patient Money column focuses on choosing a method of birth control that suits your lifestyle and your pocketbook.

headline: Talks on Opening Clinic in St. Vincent’s Building Are Stalled Over Birth Control
snippet: Officials said that there are demands that an urgent-care center planned for the old emergency room at St. Vincent’s Hospital in Greenwich Village conform to Roman Catholic doctrine.

headline: Disappointing Results at Birth Control Company
snippet: Conceptus, a maker of a form of permanent birth control, said Friday that its quarterly results fell short of forecasts, setting off a 20 percent decline in its share price.

headline: Is Consensus Possible on Birth Control?
snippet: Is a political consensus possible on birth control as a strategy to fight poverty?

headline: Risks: Birth Control Linked to Sexual Problems
snippet: A German study suggests that young women who rely on hormonal birth control are at a higher risk for sexual dysfunction than those who use nonhormonal methods.

headline: What Every Girl Should Know
snippet: A thousand years ago, eating bees was a popular method of birth control. Here’s to the 50th anniversary of the pill.
